#Text=REBECCA'S RELATIONS

#Text=They had been called the Sawyer girls when Miranda at eighteen , Jane at twelve , and Aurelia at eight participated in the various activities of village life ; and when Riverboro fell into a habit of thought or speech , it saw no reason for falling out of it , at any rate in the same century .
#Text=So although Miranda and Jane were between fifty and sixty at the time this story opens , Riverboro still called them the Sawyer girls .
#Text=They were spinsters ; but Aurelia , the youngest , had made what she called a romantic marriage and what her sisters termed a mighty poor speculation .
#Text=" There 's worse things than bein ' old maids , " they said ; whether they thought so is quite another matter .
#Text=The element of romance in Aurelia 's marriage existed chiefly in the fact that Mr. L. D. M. Randall had a soul above farming or trading and was a votary of the Muses .

#Text=He taught the weekly singing-school ( then a feature of village life ) in half a dozen neighboring towns , he played the violin and " called off " at dances , or evoked rich harmonies from church melodeons on Sundays .

#Text=He taught certain uncouth lads , when they were of an age to enter society , the intricacies of contra dances , or the steps of the schottische and mazurka , and he was a marked figure in all social assemblies , though conspicuously absent from town-meetings and the purely masculine gatherings at the store or tavern or bridge .

#Text=His hair was a little longer , his hands a little whiter , his shoes a little thinner , his manner a trifle more polished , than that of his soberer mates ; indeed the only department of life in which he failed to shine was the making of sufficient money to live upon .

#Text=Luckily he had no responsibilities ; his father and his twin brother had died when he was yet a boy , and his mother , whose only noteworthy achievement had been the naming of her twin sons Marquis de Lafayette and Lorenzo de Medici Randall , had supported herself and educated her child by making coats up to the very day of her death .
#Text=She was wont to say plaintively , " I 'm afraid the faculties was too much divided up between my twins .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= L. D. M. was practical enough to get the richest girl in the village , " replied Mrs. Robinson .

column1: #Text=" Yes , " sighed his mother , " there it is again ; if the twins could ' a ' married Aurelia Sawyer , ' t would ' a ' been all right .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Aurelia 's share of the modest Sawyer property had been put into one thing after another by the handsome and luckless Lorenzo de Medici .

#Text=He had a graceful and poetic way of making an investment for each new son and daughter that blessed their union .

_	_	_	_

#Text=A birthday present for our child , Aurelia ,  he would say , -- "a little nest-egg for the future ; " but Aurelia once remarked in a moment of bitterness that the hen never lived that could sit on those eggs and hatch anything out of them .

column1: #Text=Her love of books she inherited chiefly from her mother , who found it hard to sweep or cook or sew when there was a novel in the house .
#Text=Fortunately books were scarce , or the children might sometimes have gone ragged and hungry .
#Text=But other forces had been at work in Rebecca , and the traits of unknown forbears had been wrought into her fibre .
#Text=Lorenzo de Medici was flabby and boneless ; Rebecca was a thing of fire and spirit : he lacked energy and courage ; Rebecca was plucky at two and dauntless at five .
#Text=Mrs. Randall and Hannah had no sense of humor ; Rebecca possessed and showed it as soon as she could walk and talk .
